NEWS RELEASE

The British Academy joins with Dare to recognise the ones to watch
1 May 2007

The top young video games talent in the UK is to be recognised with a new BAFTA- endorsed award announced today.

The three winning teams from this year's Dare to be Digital competition
column3: will become the shortlist for the new BAFTA Ones to Watch Award
column4:
and the winners will be revealed at the British Academy Video Games Awards in October. BAFTA will announce this year's offical Video Games Award categories next week.

Paul Jackson
column5:
chair of the BAFTA Games committee said "A critical part of our recognition of video games as a third aspect of screen culture alongside film and TV is the celebration of the talented development stars of the future. Dare to be Digital provides a proven route for recognising talented young development teams and we are very excited at the prospect of showcasing new talent in this way."

Paul Durrant
column6: Director of Dare to be Digital
column7: said:  "We are very proud to be associated with BAFTA in this new award.  The continued UK and international expansion of Dare has enabled us to open up the Dare opportunity to a great breadth of talented students and now that Dare is the pathway to the BAFTA Ones to Watch Award
column8:
it represents a truly fabulous opportunity.â

Dare to be Digital
column9: developed and organised by the University of Abertay Dundee
column10: is the UKâs premier computer games design competition for students.  This year
column11: teams of students from across Britain and Ireland as well as teams from India and China
column12: comprising a total of around 60 students
column13:
will compete in the 10-week contest.

Teams will spend the first nine weeks based at one of three host centres in Guildford
column15:
designing and building a fully functioning prototype of their video game idea to be judged by a panel of games industry experts.

Participants receive financial support and weekly training sessions from industry specialists during the competition. In the 10th week
column16: the teams will showcase their work to the general public and industry experts at Dare ProtoPlay as part of the Edinburgh Interactive Festival
column17:
before convening at Abertay University for the final Dare to be Digital awards ceremony. The three winning teams will then form the shortlist for the new BAFTA Ones to Watch Award and will be judged according to the progress they make over the month or so following the Dare to be Digital Awards.

Paul Durrant added: âFor the top three teams
column18: the chance to experience the British Academy Video Games Awards presentation is the opportunity of a lifetime and will be a great way to demonstrate both the professional and cultural aspects of career opportunities in the video games industry. Our entries for the Scottish and Irish host centres have now closed and the selected teams will be announced shortly. Meanwhile
column19: entries for the London and South East host centre based at Electronic Artsâ UK studio in Guildford
column20:
close on 20th May so there is still an opportunity for students who are would-be game designers in London and the South East to enter.â (see www.daretobedigital.com).

Dare to be Digital has established an enviable reputation for producing high-grade talent. Teams from previous years have gone on to set up their own game development companies selling product to the worldâs major publishers. Individuals who have taken part in Dare have also been snapped up by major international games companies such as Lionhead
column23:
as well as Dundee-based developers such as Realtime Worlds and Denki.

Dare to be Digital 2007 has assembled an impressive list of sponsors
column31: the Digital Hub in Dublin and Belfast City Council with the Northern Ireland Department of Enterprise
column32:
Trade and Investmentâs Building Sustainable Prosperity Programme and Intertrade Ireland.

(Ends)

NOTES FOR EDITORS

About Dare to be Digital
Dare to be Digital was first piloted among computer games students at Abertay in 1999. The following year
column33: the first full competition was run by a partnership of the University of Abertay Dundee
column34: Scottish Enterprise Tayside and Dundee City. Until this year
column35: Dare to be Digital took place entirely in Dundee
column36:
but often including teams from the rest of the UK and overseas. Abertay Universityâs decision to almost double the number of contestants for 2007 led to the setting up of the regional host centres.

More information: www.daretobedigital.com
www.abertay.ac.uk

About BAFTA
The British Academy of Film and Television Arts is the UK's leading organisation dedicated to the recognition and promotion of excellence in the fields of the moving image. Renowned for its high profile Film
column37: Television and Video Games Awards ceremonies
column38:
the prestigious BAFTA mask has long been seen as a symbol of excellence.

Media enquiries: Amanda Slayton
